title: Wednesday, 31st January, 2018
bodyHTML:
Blank canvas good morning all
11:02 am
BE11:02am

Hello! Hi! Welcome! Hey there!

willosaurus Morgenstein!
Otter Hello internet friends.
KS Morning
AAAA Bonjour les amis !
BE11:02am

This is Markets Live, FT Alphaville's daily you know.

Soundbuy Oi
Grouchmonkey Morning
willosaurus Meltdown-a-geddon, and apostrophe-gate. Should be a good one!
Manxish Mornin
Plato the Cook Got to love efficient markets
DerivedCategory Morning
BE11:03am

Dan is joining shortly, technology allowing.

11:02 am
BE11:03am

In the meantime, have a tweet.

Deans F ...morning all!
BE11:03am

https://twitter.com/DeItaOne/status/958650351883837440

KS Capita is this week's Dignity
AAAA Klepierre ? what's the story ???
BE11:03am

................. uh.

rw42 Ugh.
11:03 am
DM11:03am

hello

DM11:03am

found my way in

BE11:03am

Hooray, it works. Morning Dan.

11:03 am
DM11:04am

refilled the hamster's water bottle

Grouchmonkey @KS and Dairy Crest this week's Kier. Market overreacting to statement saying "we are doing boringly ok"
DM11:04am

Morning Bryce, Rabble

BE11:04am

(@AAAA: literally nothing? It's down 1% on no news? Why do you ask?)

AAAA Dan, alias the Wirecard puncher
SoS private eye will have a field day with capita
pfd The surprise is that the overall market isn't lower. isn't the tide going out a bit at the moment?
11:04 am
BE11:05am

We need to start with the obvious, I guess.

Capita PLC (CPI:LSE): Last: 204.00, down 143.8 (-41.35%), High: 250.00, Low: 189.95, Volume: 13.83m
BE11:05am

Finally!

11:05 am
DM11:05am

Finally?

FJ Another capita(l punishment) for outsourcing fanboys. Comrade C. will say: "Told you so!"
Swedish Chef @sos Crapita. Shurley shome mishtake.
BE11:06am

They've delivered the kitchen sink we've been talking about for about two years.

pfd can't believe there aren't others not wearing any trunks
BE11:06am

It's required a new CEO, though.

SoS @swedish - thought that would be filtered! clearly not
11:06 am
DM11:06am

Which is producing some kickining of selves in the West End this morning

DM11:07am

Of course a new CEO was going to come in, kitchen sink, raise cash...

Pseudonym Another one where the board run it into the ground while they sort out their pensions then dump the mess on someone else and p'off into the sunshine.
pfd with the govt in disarray, plays right into Corbyn's hands.
red is anyone really surprised. one or two more go still in that area.
DM11:07am

Terrible environment, Carillion etc

RA morning kids
11:07 am
DM11:07am

But, very few to congratulate

BE11:08am

Market timing really is a sod, even when things are screamingly obvious .....

BE11:08am

I mean ....

11:08 am
BE11:08am

BE11:08am

November 2016. https://www.ft.com...-961e-a1acd97f622d

Fox LOW & BONAR. New CEO. P/E 8, Dividend 6%; trading around book price. Large new factory in China completed. Chinese take over?
BE11:08am

The "or" should've been an "and", in retrospect.

Deep Breath everyone... @BE - what clown wrote that??
RA my housemate worked for capita in their CAD design office, said the business was stagnant and no one had any desire to seek out new business
11:08 am
DM11:09am

Ah, foresight

red a however in there. i think should be credited for raising money now, while mkt cap allows it. this was carillions mistake. and i think it will be interserve too poss.
FATDAZ re Capita I said recently didn't I that other outsourcers likely had downside potential so exhibit A
DM11:09am

good job we don't have to put timings on these things

BE11:10am

So anyway, PBT guidance cut by c25%. Dividend scrapped. And they're doing the death spiral thing of pre-announcing a rights issue of "up to £700m".

FATDAZ I see BE has trumped me
11:10 am
DM11:10am

Only a few congratulations to hand out, as per the disclosed shorts - AQR (quants eh?), Capeview and Henderson

BE11:11am

That's a surprise, given how much the construction outsourcers have been crawled over in recent years.

Alchemy30 morning, TALK having a rough day
Tom Dalgleish In the old days a company name described its activites. None of the high handed BS names that proliferate now. Give me XYZ Outsourcers any day
Stateless On capita, the real question is....is it worth investing in after the cap raise?
RA anyone have any insights into fitbit? up 3.5% pre market
DM11:12am

Too much else drawing attention, maybe.

JuB Morning guys, any detail on Elliott / Sky ? Odey was calling for higher bid way back ... any colour on what lev being mooted now would be interestingany insights SKY / Fox would be interesting
Tom Dalgleish Like whoever heard of Financia Time
RA @ DM, Siemens gave a good report this morning
11:11 am
BE11:12am

Anyway, it seems Jon Lewis will never knowingly undersell his problems. Capita's “too complex, placed too great an emphasis upon short term performance, underinvested in infrastructure, over-relied upon acquisitions for growth and has limited financial flexibility, which has constrained its ability to invest for the long term benefit of the business.”

pfd @stateless. With a Labour govt on the way?
Flaneur Yet another Zombie company.... if only there'd be some hint, some clue from the Vox Populi that this would be the inevitable and blindingly f obvious outcome to the stupidest economic policy in history.Roll on the de-zombification....
DM11:12am

Sense is earnings down about 35 per cent, ngtv cash flow this year and maybe next

Stateless @pfd if you had Lab govt on way view, many better ways to profit on that
BE11:13am

Yep. Though hard to say given the currently unpriced cash call.

wayneJ But Jon Lewis can save the company - and do what King Canute failed to - by sending back the tides.
11:13 am
DM11:13am

Instinct says everyone hates outsources at the moment, and the market cap is really small now, so maybe this is a buy and tough it out down here...

DM11:14am

But, a few aspects to digest

FJ @JuB Check out how Disney dealt with Euro Disney minority shareholders. They won't overpay.
pfd @stateless. sell £?
DM11:14am

One is the environment for those who might be thinking of handing out big gov or private sector contracts in the coming months

Tom Dalgleish I read today that journalist is on of the highest stress jobs going. Law suits and low pay
Tom Dalgleish *one
Pseudonym Maybe they could split crapita into distinct mounds of crap and it?
SoS must be some Capita suppliers worrying out there today
11:15 am
DM11:15am

After the experience of Carillion, which civil servant is going to look at a company whose share price has halved and is undertaking a big cash call, and say yes, lets go for these guys?

kim @TomDid you read that in a newspaper?
DM11:16am

Think theres a bid process ongiong between Capita and Serco for a MoD contract at the moment, which bears watching

Tom Dalgleish Newsletter, Marc Faber's
Mouselet Oh well, there goes Capita. So, Serco and G4S.
Tom Dalgleish .........and CEO is low stress
DM11:16am

So it is hard to say where the revenue goes, meaning margins, meaning confidence in resolution of balance sheet probs

estrangedcapitalist Morning chaps
Mouselet Why would you buy Capita now rather than at the rights issue?
estrangedcapitalist Here in Zurich
red still a one yard mkt cap is capita. still can be a lot of downside.
11:17 am
DM11:17am

Then there is the structural question. Capita's model was basically move jobs from London to Huddersfield

estrangedcapitalist Unfortunately won't be able to make the weekly backgammon game today. Have a meeting with a Swiss banker
Pharma @Mouselet, I think your sentence would be improved by truncation after the fifth word.
estrangedcapitalist @ Mouselet will be taking over
DM11:18am

Then it became move jobs from Huddersfield to India

Mouselet There is still Burkina Faso
DM11:18am

Stage three, is replace fleshy humans with predictive text chat bots and outsourcing as a service

Mouselet but the infrastructure requirements before you can outsource to Burkina Faso are such that you'd probably have an easier job just building the blasted call centre in Huddersfield
11:18 am
BE11:18am

Robot back office automation. Yep.

Bonnemort To be fair Capita was a creature of the Blair years - didn't it's former CEO lend them a million or so?
Mouselet also Francophone which isn't great for call centres
Grouchmonkey Spoke to someone in the army - Capita is NOT their favourite company
FATDAZ just reading that Mexico has a lower cost work force than China
DM11:19am

AI, robots, buzzwords, etc. I'm not sure these are necessarily Capita's strengths

Mouselet Who *do* you go for as a CEO who has read about back office automation in his in-flight magazine?
BE11:19am

Indeed not. It's going to need reinvention from here.

11:19 am
DM11:20am

So we have a structural problem combined with a balance sheet problem, combined with a terrible environment for weak outsourcers

Woz10 TALK tanking again...
wayneJ Robots from Huddersfield?
Swedish Chef Rang Amex last week. Thought call would be answered in Brighton. Nah, Manila.
BE11:20am

Hm. I was also reminded this morning of the shock horror stuff in the papers post Carillion that the government was awarding contracts to a company after it had had multiple profit warnings .........

red seems near term contracts and making cash on them will make or break this puppy
red lets hope they arent building any roads
BE11:20am

Which doesn't really bode well for Capita's order book, I'd hazard.

11:20 am
BE11:21am

Nevertheless, there's an argument that today's price could overshoot because the warning will lead to a lot of churn of the shareholder base -- not least among income funds who exit on the divi suspension.

BE11:21am

Let me grab some sellside to get an idea of where forecasts are going.

FJ The Outsourcing sector needs consolidation, not more capital injections
red does appear unless very well drilled that biz plan not commercially viable. that goes for the space.
BE11:22am

Simple read from Stifel .....

Mouselet have been proceeding along the A14 the last two days, there are rather fewer heavy yellow equipments building the road than one would hope for
Soundbuy Talk Talk off 16% - is there a note doing the rounds....??
11:22 am
BE11:22am

[M]arket conditions remain challenging and FY18 expectations have been significantly rebased with the company guiding to adj. PBT of £270m-£300m. Under the current number of shares and taking the mid-point of that range this would represent an adj. EPS of c.33p. Our current estimates show adj. PBT of £385m and adj. EPS of 45.2p.

Mouselet somebody talked to a Talk Talk user?
Bonnemort Employers = Wicked Queen, Outsourcers = huntsman, TUPE'd staff = Snow White
BE11:22am

Our initial take is that whilst this will be a painful process for Capita's shareholders in the short term, the steps announced by the company this morning are necessary to ensure the long-term viability of the group

BE11:22am

(@Soundbuy: Talktalk's an Exane downgrade. We'll get to it.)

Mouselet FJ: consolidation in a sector which has gone from 4 to 3 by the operation of the very visible hand of The Liquidator ?
11:22 am
BE11:23am

And Jefferies.

BE11:23am

Our initial calculations suggest that FY18E consensus EPS estimates, once analysts have included rights issue and bonus factor adjustments, could decline by c40% today. In the medium term, cost savings should help (we think £85-90m could be achievable) but the revenue environment remains lacklustre.

BE11:24am

And some conference call feedback. Morgan Stanley.

AAAA talk talk : Exane’s Sam McHugh cuts his price target to 90p
11:24 am
BE11:24am

Capita is expecting flat revenue in 2018, but this is based on some large wins (including DFRP, where it is competing with Serco, as well as the BA customer contact outsourcing), smaller wins and software sales offsetting the expected 5% attrition in FY18, so has “risk” to revenue and earnings. Capita believes that it is well-positioned to serve customers for digital transformation, which we don’t believe is the case and could lead to further attrition in the businesses flagged as headwinds for 2018. In addition, 2018 will be a year of investment and so may 2019 and cash flow should remain negative in 2018 and could do so in 2019, which ties in with its comments that it’s a 2 years transformation plan.

DM11:25am

(RA - Siemens? do share Dan.Mccrum@ft.com)

BE11:25am

... and Citi.

11:25 am
BE11:25am

Capita ended FY17 with £1.15bn net debt. When adjusting for a range of items including £110m receivables factoring, £130m working capital normalisation, £130m deferred income reduction, £215m other items (including related to the CAS disposal and Connaught) the pro forma net debt could potentially be closer to £1.7bn, we think.

Fox Anyone think the drop over at SAGA is way overdone? Gross profits of £400M/annum; P/E now just 8 and Dividend yielding 8% with cover 1.5x? IPO was at 185p in 2014 now trading at just 115p? Do fundamentals like P/E no longer matter when you have this below 10 and others like Just Eat, SSPG, Abcam 40-50x earnings
BE11:26am

Taking the midpoint of the £270-300m PBT management guidance and adjusting for estimated £55m net finance charge and £105m depreciation, we calculate implied guidance of £445m EBITDA. While management’s assumption for 0% organic sales growth might prove “best case scenario” and is dependent on new contract wins, PBT guidance should be little affected by a small shortfall given low upfront profit take on new contracts under IFRS 15. The guidance is however pre-disposals, which are likely to be dilutive.

DM11:26am

(@Tom Dalgleish, but the fun we get to have interacting with you lot makes up for it)

11:26 am
BE11:26am

Disposal requirements — given this level of EBITDA, the journey to 2x net debt/EBITDA (the top of the 1-2x targeted range by management) given c£700m from the rights issue suggests c£200m required disposal proceeds. 1x net debt /EBITDA could mean up to £600-700m proceeds. The implication is that there are likely to be material disposals in addition to the two named by management (ParkingEye and Constructionline).

BE11:27am

And I think that's plenty for Capita, right?

undefined
11:27 am
BE11:27am

Right, so TalkTalk .....

red @Foxnot sure fox, revs under pressure i think
BE11:27am

........... as mentioned on the right about fifteen hundred times.

DM11:27am

Everybody's favourite broadband supplier

A What is everyon's view on RNWH?
11:27 am
DM11:28am

What's up?

BE11:28am

It's Exane doing the damage. Monster sector piece on UK telco, And the conclusion is that it's not everyone's favourite broadband supplier.

DM11:28am

Or down, in this case

Forester @fox well I am in there (with a long term view)...but appear to be in the minority!
11:28 am
BE11:28am

Exane mines Google Trend Data to suggest that Britons are absolutely bloody sick of their broadband bills getting squeezed higher.

DM11:29am

What do they search for?

Flaneur Too many companies selling white-labelled, generic service. Little chance of expansion as we are reaching the 'good enough' level for most users.
BE11:29am

That's a good question. I don't remember.

Tom Dalgleish Google trend is quite clumsy in my view
11:30 am
BE11:30am

However, whatever it was, the conclusion is that BT's pissed in the well. with multiple increases each year. Argument is that BT has pushed prices up too far and is now a brand in decline, with increasing reliance on the low ARPU brands of Plusnet and EE.

BE11:30am

So, discount growth is hugely outpacing premium, which smashes ARPU across the entire sector.

BE11:30am

Which should be good for TalkTalk. Except it isn't, because TalkTalk isn't a price leader.

Forester I just got stung $70 for a domain renewal.....turn your back for 5 mins these days and you get gouged!
Big Red Noticed the "Builders" subject to political mischief making again. Some are likely a good buy if you consider special dividends, place trade as a Spread and take the view that you will get your original price paid sometime this year.
11:30 am
BE11:31am

Quick check of a price comparison thingmy showed this morning that Sky, Post Office, Plusnet, First Broadband and EE will do you cheaper copper than Talktalk's £19.95 a month, while Vodafone will do you fibre for 5p more.

DM11:31am

Oh, what is TalkTalk if it isn't the cheapest?

BE11:31am

Well, exactly.

Flaneur We have a home internet connection and a seperate 3/4g connection on several mobiles. Just how much capacity do we need to look at Youtube videos or look up beef wellington recipes?
red yes there ia always that. british folks and their experiences with bt. there is always that for talk talk and anyone else. plus its essentially a tax as a must have service now isnt it.
11:31 am
BE11:32am

It doesn't do tri play or quad play or whatever and it doesn't have the balance sheet to compete with Sky, who can do broadband as a loss leader for TV subs.

rw42 Looking forward to new flat - Hyperoptic doing the fibre there, 1gbit available! Problem is with most of these companies is no matter who you're paying money to it still talks to BT at some point..
Bonnemort Co Op broadband (!) about £45 a month including all calls save overseas
BE11:32am

Let me quote what I can of Exane, which isn't much.

BE11:32am

The premium segment of the UK broadband market is set to go ex-growth in 2018. Consumers are increasingly seeking low price offers, putting downward pressure on ARPU and returns across the industry. This (alongside B2B) informs our continued bearish view on BT (-, 240p).

red @Flaneurits a q of what u need. we dont have cable on our estate but the lte connection is fine for doing everything. apart from games i assume. but we dont play online so its no loss if thats the case.
11:32 am
BE11:32am

Historically TalkTalk has been the primary beneficiary of consumers spinning down, but this is no longer the case. Their trading momentum appears to have peaked, and their share of the discount market is coming under renewed pressure. We think there is another dividend cut ahead, and cut our price target by 35% to 90p.

Tom Dalgleish We have no copper remaining here and fibre never reaches nameplate speed
Bonnemort (use TalkTalk as carrier)
DM11:33am

(@Fox - Saga is ex private equity, which is not a popular club atm)

dfd @Forester - yes I've bought some Saga now, but based on friend who works there. Says its best run co. he's ever worked for, so we'll see.
Forester @flaneur more and more....my 16yo daughter used 1.5 terrabytes last month!
rw42 Can see required bandwidth going up as more TV consumption is online on demand rather than sky, most games are relatively low bandwidth to play, only downloading them in the first place needs anything decent.
KS Aren't Sky getting rid of dishes in favour of doing everything via Internet?
Tom Dalgleish I dont like the SAGA chart at all
BE11:34am

TalkTalk's next report - "19k on-net broadband additions, a slowdown vs the 20k and 26k of the last two quarters" - is more interesting for the trend than the continued growth, which is probably unsustainable as they continue to haemorrhage customers.

Tom Dalgleish Can a souffle rise twice?
Pharma @rw42, low bandwidth requirement for games, but you need low latency, which is the tricky part in a congested network.
Mouselet console games tend to have ten-gigabyte updates every couple of weeks
Pseudonym The problem with the broadband providers is that they produce neither the tech nor the network, so any new development that comes along they all get at the same time. There's no differentiation.
11:35 am
BE11:35am

And as we've noted in the past, customers are now rolling off the TalkTalk's permanent low price promise contracts and discovering that permanent low prices only applied to broadband.

BE11:36am

Not calls, line rental, etc.

Pseudonym The competition is therefore entirely about margin limbo.
Mouselet price-sensitive customers by definition have low ARPU and *move*
BE11:36am

Which is an excellent way to annoy your customer base and encourage churn.

Mouselet BT is big enough to invent new tech, but too regulated to introduce a new network
Forester Moved from TT to BT Infitinty 2 - more expensive but faster and more reliable for a gaming obsessed household!
11:36 am
BE11:37am

We last wrote about this stuff here: https://www.ft.com...-a8a4-0a1e63a52f9c

BE11:37am

And will do again, I'm sure. Anyway, that's that.

undefined
Fox Pan African Resources (PAF) bidding for ASA Resources assets (now defunct). Could double asset base and share price from 13p? 300oz production soon.
FJ Always ask if you really get the bandwidth they promise you...
11:37 am
BE11:37am

Housebuilders due a mention.

Pseudonym @Mouselet I don't think BT has any kind of R&D resource any more though outside the network business and anything they do there they have to offer to everyone else.
Taylor Wimpey PLC (TW.:LSE): Last: 190.60, down 4.5 (-2.31%), High: 194.40, Low: 190.60, Volume: 7.14m
Barratt Developments PLC (BDEV:LSE): Last: 588.40, down 12.4 (-2.06%), High: 601.40, Low: 588.40, Volume: 1.91m
Fox Low&Bonar top of the FTSE risers
11:38 am
Berkeley Group Holdings PLC (BKG:LSE): Last: 3,982, down 70 (-1.73%), High: 4,048, Low: 3,975, Volume: 300.60k
Persimmon PLC (PSN:LSE): Last: 2,509, down 62 (-2.41%), High: 2,560, Low: 2,507, Volume: 519.91k
DM11:38am

Shouldn't that be "greedy housebuilders"?

Forester @FJ back when TT were the cheapest "unlimted" package a tolerated the "squeeze" at peak times....but not now.
hedgehog Aa next for div cut and raise?
Tom Dalgleish Low and Boehner
Blank canvas Cineworld all over the place this morning ahead of Friday's meeting. Any thoughts. No personal interest, just curious.
BornCynic How about Carney wanting rid of RPI? Took him a long time to work out it costs him 1% more than CPI.......
11:39 am
BE11:39am

It all follows that theme, yes. And they're getting beaten up on a government minister announcing the possible conclusions of a review before the review's even finished.

BE11:40am

FOBTs last time. Landbanking this time.

DogsEars Would be good to hear thoughts on CINE
BE11:40am

Which made for a nicely aggro front page of the Times this morning, though what it actually means is anyone's guess: https://www.thetim...to-build-xg9jshchd

red think rising bond yields a isnt helping housebuilders either
rw42 Would love to see a bband provider offering meaningful cheaper subscription costs if you don't actually want to take voice calls on the same line! Feels like just gouging to split line rental / bband cost when the phone stays unplugged..
11:41 am
BE11:41am

To retread the theme, we've already had several reviews of landbanking and none of them has found that it exists.

Upaswellasdown Morning all. Any developments on Stanley Gibbons?
BE11:42am

What difference would “use it or lose it” planning permissions make? Dunno. Probably not much, as everyone in the industry seems to believe that the pinch point is before planning permissions are granted.

madrugada FOX: I can think of a number of companies that are cheap and paying a good dividend. If you think something is undervalued then buy it and be patient.
BE11:42am

Here's Caz.

11:42 am
BE11:42am

We continue to view this as a small or non-issue for housebuilders, who begin to build on consented land as and when they receive permission. The slow pace of receiving permissions continues to be a restriction on volume growth.

BE11:42am

And Goodbody.

BE11:42am

Housebuilders have denied hoarding land, arguing that it does not make sense to have land sitting idle once planning permission has been granted. Indeed, some developers warn that government action on land-banking could backfire and said that they would fight it in the courts. Given the UK’s reliance on the large housebuilders to meet its objective of 300,000 completions per annum it is hard to see that the government would retrospectively revoke planning permissions. However, continued speculation in the papers is unhelpful for sentiment around the sector.

Mouselet rw42: isn't the problem that Openreach prices like that and so other providers can't escape it?
11:44 am
BE11:44am

A reminder that the landbanking review was announced at the Autumn budget. I'm not convinced there's much new here.

undefined
Grouchmonkey Re Landbanking - how does it work if the Co has an option, rather than holding the undeveloped land? That seems to be standard practice these days.
DM11:45am

An end of dry January call?

11:45 am
BE11:45am

Oh really?

DM11:46am

Something from the UBS "Evidence Lab", which I've always enjoyed imagining as room in the middle of their research floor where they don white lab coats.

DM11:47am

Today's subject is the future of beer, which is non-beer

madrugada BE: I love your last sentence: continued speculation in the papers is unhelpful for sentiment around the sector. Isn’t this the case with press speculation regarding bookmakers? They got whacked a few weeks ago.
Blue horseshoe... Ashland Global...?...feb options buying yday
dfd Enuiries into landbanking etc are nonsense. Government knows you can't make new houses cheaper without undermining value of voters existing houses, so it wont happen.
11:47 am
DM11:47am

or rather the beside the point low alcohol/no alcohol version

DM11:47am

which seems redundant now we have potable water on tap

DM11:48am

But the lab has surveyed 6,000 consumers in the UK, France and Spain

11:48 am
DM11:48am

UBS Evidence Lab conducted online surveys of 6,000 beverage consumers in three of the largest European beer markets: UK, France & Spain. The percentage of consumers likely to try a low-/no-alcohol beer in the next 12mths varies from 18% in the UK to 45% in Spain. Consumers drink low-/no-alcohol beer as they wish to reduce alcohol consumption yet continue to enjoy the same taste/flavour as regular beer. The main occasion for low-/no-alcohol beer is 'at home' consumption (51% of respondents).

Miss Piggy @dfd: 90% with you there. except if Govt gets bug pension firms to build large blocks of flats for rent, so build to rent, then the linkage to owner occupiers is weaker.
Miss Piggy *big pension firms*
Xanthine The argument that this government won't do something economically damaging for the sake of fulfilling a political narrative and pacifying the tabloids seems ... hopeful.
DM11:49am

Because the perfect time to drink alcohol free beer is at home, not the pub or a party where driving is involved

Upaswellasdown I'm a big fan of non-alcoholic beer. I am that easily fooled.
DM11:49am

Huge global potential for low-/no-alcohol beer, Heineken top-pick
European beer volumes have been under structural pressure in recent years owing to demographics, stricter drink driving laws & share losses to wines and spirits (see our primer for more detail). Brewers are therefore investing heavily in growing segments such as craft, cider & low-/no-alcohol beer. In this report we investigate the latter in more detail as it offers an opportunity to gain share from other categories (e.g. soft drinks) and has significantly higher margins than most alcohol (given little to no excise). While the segment is small today with

GBKrona @BE / DM - will you take that with sugar? Any comments on Britvic's trading statement pls?
11:50 am
DM11:50am

There is a small roadblock

Markkus @rw42 Vodafone do not charge line rental on their fibre packages. 'Course you can argue that it's built in to the monthly charge.
red @Miss Piggythe last bastion is owning ones house. the new gig economy rent/beg/borrow drive is chipping away at everything but so far folks still want to own houses. many cant afford but still want. that may change who knows.
DM11:50am

The biggest challenge in the category is the negative perception of taste/flavour. For the ~60% of respondents that haven't tried low-/no-alcohol beer before, ~1/4 cite the main reason for not doing so is displeasing taste/flavour. However when looking at respondents that have tried it, ~45% believe it replicates the taste of an alcoholic beer. This leads us to believe that as more consumers trial it for the first time, at least some portion will find the taste sufficiently satisfying and similar to alcoholic beer.

Rick Chasey Seen non-alcoholic beer advertised as a good 'post-exercise recovery drink' which I know a lot of people have bought into.
willosaurus I used lime-soda as my dry January prop. There is a staggering variation in price for that drink.
BE11:51am

"The biggest challenge in the category" is the fact that it doesn't get you drunk.

GBKrona @Markkus - Voda fibre is a con - I live in SE1 and they just redirect you to a non-fibre product similar to BT/Talk
11:51 am
DM11:51am

I drink beer for the taste, my girlfriend lives in Canada...

Grouchmonkey Alcoholic beer to go out of fashion after a mere 4,000 years of popularity? Seems unlikely. Brewers share prices looking sickly, though.
BE11:52am

Indeed. Brendan Behan summed up the essential characteristic of beer. And I'm not going to put UBS above Brendan Behan on the subject of drinking, even if the former has an "evidence lab".

However, opposition isn't unanimous. Here's Loop Capital's summary of where things stand.

Markkus @GBKrona - this message comes to you via Voda fibre. I'm syncing at 74mB which is faster than BT Infinity 2 managed on the same line.
BE11:54am

TTM EBIT for RGC, non-adjusted, was $276.0mm, not including results anticipated for Q4 (RGC hasn't reported yet), so an acquisition by CINE would require a combination of fairly aggressive stock and debt issuance, and it's that reality, plus the fact that CINE shares have corrected 25.8% over the past two months, that according to recent reports in various trade publications, has Institutional Shareholder Services (ISS) issuing a formal opinion that CINE shareholders vote against the deal. Other top ten shareholders, mostly U.K.-based funds, have also publicly expressed verbal disapproval of the deal due to the high leverage. That said, according to other recent reports, Glass-Lewis has weighed in and recommends CINE shareholders vote in favor of the deal, as has Global City Holdings, based in Poland, which is CINE's largest shareholder at 28.0%. PIRC, or Pensions and Investment Research Consultants, based in London, has also weighed in and has recommended CINE shareholders vote for the deal.

BE12:07pm

We were fans of Micro Focus, but went to Hold on the HPE deal. The scale of the integration, lack of evidence that the underlying Micro Focus had yet stabilised and HPE’s vast and largely undifferentiated software stack diluting Micro Focus differentiation (COBOL, SUSE) concerned us. Recent results underwhelmed and our concerns have escalated rather than abated, and a material H2 weighting and forecast risk prevents a long-term valuation view. Our TP is at the lower end of our 1900p-2150p fair value range and we downgrade to Sell.
